Will keepe me for his sport, a moneth, or two,
To shew me with my fellow Cittizens.
I must make his traine long, and full, one quarter;
And helpe the spectacle of his greatnesse. There,
Nothing is done at once, but injuries, boy:
And they come head-long! all their good turnes move not,
Or very slowly.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yet sweet father, trust him.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Well, I will thinke..

sp.speaker: Ev.
sp.l: Come, you must do't, Sir.
I'am undone else, and your Lady Tail-bush
Has sent for me to dinner, and my cloaths
Are all at pawne. I had sent out this morning,
Before I heard you were come to towne, some twenty
Of my Epistles, and no one returne—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, I ha' told you o'this. This comes of wearing
Mere-craft tells him of his faults. Scarlet, gold lace, and cut-works! your fine gartring!
With your blowne roses, Cousin! and your eating
Phesant, and Godwit. here in London! haunting
The Globes, and Mermaides! and wedging in with Lords,
Still at the table! and affecting lechery,
In velvet! where could you ha' contented your selfe
With cheese, salt-butter, and a pickled hering,
I'the Low-countries; there worne cloth, and fustian!
Beene satisfied with a leape o'your Host's daughter,
In garrison, a wench of a stoter! or,
Your Sutlers wife, i'the leaguer, of two blanks!
You never, then, had runne upon this flat,
To write your letters missive, and send out
Your privy seales, that thus have frighted off
All your acquaintance; that they shun you at distance,
Worse, then you do the Bailies!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Pox upon you.
I come not to you for counsell, He repines, I lack money.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You doe not thinke, what you owe me already?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I?
They owe you that meane to pay you. I'll be sworne,
I never meant it. Come, you will project,
I shall undoe your practice, and threatens him. for this moneth 〈◊〉
You know me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I yo'are a right sweet nature!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Well, that's all one!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You'll leave this Empire, one day?
You will not ever have this tribute payd,
Your scepter o'the sword?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Tye up your wit,
Doe, and provoke me not—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you, Sir, helpe,
To what I shall provoke another for you?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I cannot tell; try me: I thinke I am not
So utterly, of an ore un-to-be-melted,
But I can doe my selfe good, on occasions.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Strike in then, They joynes for your part. Mr. Fitz-dottrel
If I transgresse in point of manners, afford me
Your best construction; I must beg my freedome
From your affaires, this day.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: How, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: It is
In succor of this Gentlemans occasions, Meere-craft pretends businesse.
My kins-man—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: You'll not doe me that affront, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I am sorry you should so interpret it,
But, Sir, it stands upon his being invested,
In a new, office, he has stood for, long:
Master of the Dependances! Meere-craft describes the office of Dependancy .A place
Of my projection too, Sir, and hath met
Much opposition; but the State, now see's
That great necessity of it, as after all
Their writing, and their speaking, against Divells,
They have erected it. His booke is drawne—
For, since, there will be differences, daily,
'Twixt Gentlemen; and that the roaring manner
Is growne offensive; that those few, we call
The civill men o'the sword, abhorre the vapours;
They shall refer now, hither, for their processe;
And such as trespasse 'gainst the rule of Court,
Are to be fin'd—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: In troth, a pretty place!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A kinde of arbitrary Court 'twill be, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I shall have matter for it, I beleeve,
Ere it be long: I had a distast.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But now, Sir,
My learned councell, they must have a feeling,
They'll part, Sir, with no bookes, without the hand gout
Be oyld, and I must furnish. If 't be money,
To me streight. I am Mine, Mint and Exchequer,
To supply all. What is't? a hundred pound?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: No th'Harpey, now stands on a hundred pieces.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why, he must have 'hem, if he will. To morrow, Sir,
Will equally serve your occasion's,—
And therefore, let me obtaine, that you will yeeld
To timing a poore Gentlemans distresses,
In termes of hazard.—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: By no meanes!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I must
Get him him this money, and will.—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Sir, I protest,
I'd rather stand engag'd for it my selfe:
Then you should leave me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O good Sir, doe you thinke
So coursely of our manners, that we would,
For any need of ours, be prest to take it:
Though you be pleas'd to offer it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why by heaven,
I meane it!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I can never beleeve lesse.
He offers to be gone. But we, Sir, must preserve our dignity,
As you doe publish yours. By your faire leave, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: As I am a Gentleman, if you doe offer
To leave me now, or if you doe refuse me,
I will not thinke you love me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, I honour you.
And with just reason, for these noble notes,
Of the nobility, you pretend too! But, Sir—
I would know, why? a motive (he a stranger)
You should doe this?

sp.speaker: (Eve.
sp.l: You'll mar all with your finenesse)

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, that's all one, if 'twere, Sir, but my fancy.
But I have a Businesse, that perhaps I'd have
Brought to his office.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, Sir! I have done, then;
If he can be made profitable, to you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, and it shall be one of my ambitions
To have it the first Businesse? May I not?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: So you doe meane to make't, a perfect Businesse.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay I'll doe that assure you: shew me once.

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: Sir, 〈◊〉 concernes, the first be a perfect Businesse,
For his own honour!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I, and th'reputation
To of my place.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, why, doe I take this course, else?
〈◊〉 not altogether, an Asse, good Gentlemen,
Wherefore should I consult you? doe you thinke?
To make a song on't? How's your manner? tell us.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Doe, satisfie him: give him the whole course.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: First, by request, or otherwise you offer
Your Businesse to the Court: wherein you crave:
The judgement of the Master and the Assistants.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, that's done, now, what doe you upon it?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: We streight Sir, haue recourse to the spring-head;
Visit the ground; and so disclose the nature:
If it will carry, or no. If we doe finde,
By your proportions it is like to prove
A sullen, and blacke Bus'nesse That it be
Incorrigible; and out of, treaty; then,
We file it, a Dependance!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: So 'tis fil'd.
What followes? I doe love the order of these things.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: We then advise the party, if he be
A man of meanes and havings▪ that forth-with,
He settle his estate: if not, at least
That he pretend it. For, by that, the world
Takes notice, thatt inow is a Dependance.
And this we call, Sir, Publication.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Very sufficient! After Publication, now?

sp.speaker: Eve
sp.l: Then we grant out our Processe, which is divers;
Either by Chartell, Sir, or ore-tenus,
Wherein the Challenger, and Challengee
Or (with your Spaniard) your Provocador,
And Provocado, have their severall courses—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I have enough on't! for an hundred pieces?
Yes, for two hundred, under-write me doe.
Your man will take my bond?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That he will, sure,
But, these same Citizens, they are such sharks!
There's an old debt of forty, He whispers Fitz-dottrel aside. I ga'my word
For one is runne away, into the Bermudas,
And he will hooke in that, or he wi'not doe.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why let him. That and the ring, and a hundred pieces,
Will all but make two hundred?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, And then Guilt-head. no more, Sir.
What ready Arithmetique you have? do you heare?
A pretty mornings worke for you, this? Do it,
You shall ha' twenty pound on't.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Twenty pieces?

sp.speaker: (Plu.
sp.l: Good Father, do't)

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You will hooke still? well,
Shew us your ring. You could not ha'done this, now
With gentlenesse, at first, we might ha' thank'd you?
But groane, and ha'your courtesies come from you
Like a hard stoole, and stinke? A man may draw
Your teeth out easier, then your money? Come,
Were little Guilt-head heere, no better a nature,
I should ne'r love him, He pulls Plutarchus by the lips. that could pull his lips off, now!
Was not thy mother a Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And went to the Court at Christmas, and St. Georges-tide?
And lent the Lords-men, chaines?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Of gold, and pearle, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I knew, thou must take, after some body!
Thou could'st not be else. This was no shop-looke
I'll ha'thee Captaine Guilt-head, and march up,
And take in Pimlico, and kill the bush,
At every taverne! Thou shalt have a wife,
If smocks will mount, He turns to old Guilt-head. boy. How now? you ha'there now
Some Bristo-stone, or Cornish counterfet
You'ld put upon us.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: No, Sir, I assure you:
Looke on his luster! he will speake himselfe!
I'le gi'you leave to put him i'the Mill,
H'is no great, large stone, but a true Paragon,
H'has all his corners, view him well.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: H'is yellow.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Vpo'my faith, Sir, o'the right black-water,
And very deepe! H'is set without a foyle, too.
Here's one o'the yellow water, I'll sell cheape.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And what doe you valew this at? thirty pound?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: No, Sir, he cost me forty, ere he was set.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Turnings, you meane? I know your Equinocks:
You'are growne the better Fathers of'hem o'late,
Well, where't must goe, twill be judg'd, and therefore,
Looke you't be right. You shall have fifty pound for't.
Now to Fitz-dottrel .Not a deneer more! And because you would
Have things dispatch'd, Sir, I'll goe presently,
Inquire out this Lady, If you thinke good Sir.
Having an hundred pieces ready, you may
Part with those, now, to serve my kinsmans turnes,
That he may wait upon you, anon, the freer;
And take 'hem when you ha' seal'd, againe, of Guilt-head.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I care not if I doe!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And dispatch all,
Together,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Th'are just: a hundred pieces!
I' ha' told 'hem over, twice a day, these two months.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He turnes 'hem out together. And Everill and he fall to share. Well, goe and seale then, Sir, make your returne
As speedy as you can.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come gi' me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Soft Sir.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Marry, and faire too, then. I'll no delaying, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But you will heare?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Yes, when I have my divident.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There's forty pieces for you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: What is this for?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Your halfe. You know that Guilt-head must ha' twenty.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And what's your ring there? shall I ha' none o'that?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, that's to be given to a Lady!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Is't so?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: By that good light, it is.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, gi'me
Ten pieces more then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: For Guilt, head? Sir,
Doe you thinke, I'll 'low him any such share.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You must.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Must I? Doe you your musts, Sir, I'll doe mine,
You wi'not part with the whole, Sir? Will you? Goe too.
Gi' me ten pieces!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: By what law doe you this?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: E'n Lyon-law, Sir, I must roare else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Good!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Yo'have heard, how th' Asse made his divisions wisely?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And I am he, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Much good doe you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I shall be rid o'this tyranny, one day?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Not,
While you doe eate, and lie about the towne here;
And coozen i'your bullions and I stand
Your name of credit, and compound your businesse;
Adjourne beatings every terme; and make
New parties for your projects. I have now
A pretty tasque of it, to hold you in
Wi'your Lady Taile-bush: but the toy will be,
How we shall both come off?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Leave your doubting,
And doe your portion, what's assign'd you: I
Never fail'd yet.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: With reference to your aides?
You'll still be unthankfull. Where shall I meete you anon?
You ha' some feate to be done alone, now, I see;
You wish me gone, well, I will finde you out,
And bring you after to the audit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: S'light!
There's Ingines share too, I had forgot! This raigne
Is too-too unsuportable! I must
Quit my selfe of this vassalege! Ingine! welcome.

div.head: Act. III. Scene. IV.
div.l: HOw goes the cry?

sp.speaker: Ing
sp.l: Excellent well!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wil't do?
Where's Robinson?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Here is the Gentleman, Sir.
Will undertake t'himselfe. I have acquainted him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why did you so?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Why, Robinson would ha'told him,
You know. And he's a pleasant wit! will hurt
Nothing you purpose. Then, he'is of opinion,
That Robinson might have audacity,
She being such a gallant. Now, he has beene,
In Spaine, and knowes the fashions there, and can
Discourse; and being but mirth (he saies) leave much,
To his care:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But he is too tall!

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: For that,
He has the bravest device! He excepts at his stature. (you'll love him for't)
To say, he weares Cioppines: and they doe so
In Spaine. And Robinson's as tall, as he.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Is he so?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Every jot.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, I had rather
To trust a Gentleman with it, o'the two.

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: Pray you goe to him, then, Sir, and salute him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, my friend Ingine has acquainted you
With a strange businesse, here.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A merry one, Sir.
The Duke of Droun'd land, and his Dutchesse?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.
Now, that the Conjurers ha' laid him by,
I ha'made bold to borrow him a while;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: With purpose, yet, to put him out I hope
To his best use?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For that small part,
That I am trusted with, put off your care:
I would not lose to doe it, for the mirth,
Will follow of it; and well I have a fancy.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, that will make it well.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You will report it so.
Where must I have my dressing?

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: At my house, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You shall have caution, Sir, for what he yeelds,
To six pence.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You shall pardon me. I will share, Sir,
I' your sports, only: nothing i'your purchase.
But you must furnish me with complements,
To th'manner of Spaine; my coach, my guarda duenn'as;

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ingine's your Pro'vedor. But, Sir, I must
(Now I'have entred trust wi'you, thus farre)
Secure still i'your quality, acquaint you
With somewhat, beyond this. The place design'd
To be the Scene, for this our merry matter,
Because it must have countenance of women,
To draw discourse, and offer it, is hereby,
At the Lady Taile-bushes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I know her, Sir,
And her Gentleman huisher.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Mr. Ambler?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, it shall be no shame to me, to confesse
To you that we poore Gentlemen, that want acres,
Must for our needs, turne fooles up, and plough Ladies
Sometimes, to try what glebe they are: and this
Is no unfruitfull piece. She and I now,
Are on a project for the fact, and venting
Of a new kinde of fucus (paint for Ladies)
To serve the kingdome: wherein she her selfe
Hath travell'd, specially by way of service
Vnto her sexe, and hopes to get the Monopoly,
As the reward of her invention.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What is her end, in this?

sp.speaker: Ev.
sp.l: Merely ambition,
Sir, to grow great, and court it with the secret:
Though she pretend some other. For she's dealing,
Already, upon caution for the shares,
And Mr. Ambler, is he nam'd Examiner
For the ingredients; and the Register
Of what is vented; and shall keepe the Office.
Now, if she breake with you, of this (as I
Must make the leading thred to your acquaintance,
That how experience gotten i'your being
Abroad, will helpe our businesse) thinke of some
Pretty additions, but to keepe her floting:
It may be, she will offer you a part,
Any strange names of—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, I have my instructions.
Is it not high time to be making ready?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, Sir,

sp.speaker: Ing.
sp.l: The foole's in sight, Dottrel.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Away then.

div.head: Act. III. Scene. V.
div.l: REturn'd so soone?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, here's the ring: I ha' seal'd.
But there's not so much gold in all the row, he saies—
Till't come fro' the Mint. 'Tis tane up for the gamsters.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There's a shop-shift! plague on'hem.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: He do's sweare it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He'll sweare, and forsweare too, it is his trade,
You should not have left him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: S'lid, I can goe backe,
And beat him, yet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, now let him alone.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I was so earnest, after the maine Businesse,
To have this ring, gone.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True, and 'tis time.
I have learn'd, Sir, sin'you went, her Ladiship eats
With the Lady Tail-bush, here, hard by.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I'the lane here?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, if yo'had a servant, now of presence,
Well cloth'd, and of an aëry voluble tongue,
Neither too bigge, or little for his mouth,
That could deliver your wives complement;
To send along withall.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I have one Sir,
A very handsome, gentleman-like-fellow,
That I doe meane to make my Dutchesse Vsher—
I entertain'd him, but this morning, too:
I'll call him to you. The worst of him, is his name!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: She'll take no note of that, but of his message.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Divell! He shewes him his Pug. How like you him, Sir. Pace, go a little.
Let's see you move.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: He'll serve, Sir, give it him:
And let him goe along with me, I'll helpe
To present him, and it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Looke, you doe sirah,
Discharge this well, as you expect your place.
Do'you heare, Gives him instructions. goe on, come off with all your honours.
I would faine see him, do it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Trust him, with it;

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Remember kissing of your hand, and answering
With the French-time, in flexure of your body.
I could not so instruct him— and for his words—

sp.speaker: Mer
sp.l: I'll put them in his mouth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, but I have 'hem
O'the very Academies!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, you'll have use for'hem,
Anon, He longs to see the play. your selfe, I warrant you: after dinner,
When you are call'd.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: S'light, that'll be just play-time.
It cannot be, I must not lose the play!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, Because it is the Divell. but you must, if she appoint to sit.
And, she's president.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: S'lid, it is the Divell!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And 'twere his Damme too, you must now apply
Your selfe, Sir, to this, wholly; or lose all.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: If I could but see a piece—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir. Never think on't.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come but to one act, and I did not care—
But to be seene to rise, and goe away,
To vex the Players, and to punish their Poet—
Keepe him in awe!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But say, that he be ont,
Wi'not be aw'd! but laugh at you. How then?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Then he shall pay for'his dinner himselfe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Perhaps,
He would do that twice, rather then thanke you.
Come, get the Diuell out of your head, my Lord,
(I'll call you so in private still) and take
Your Lord-ship i'your minde. He puts him in mind of his quarrell. You were, sweet Lord,
In talke to bringe a Businesse to the Office.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why should not you, Sir, carry it o'your selfe,
Before the Office be up? and shew the world,
You had no need of any mans direction;
In point, Sir, of sufficiency. I speake
Against a kinsman, but as one that tenders
Your graces good.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I thanke you; to proceed—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: To Publications: ha'your Deed drawne presently.
And leave a blancke to put in your Feoffees
One, two, or more, as you see cause—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I thanke you
Heartily, I doe thanke you. Not a word more,
I pray you, as you love me. Let me alone.
He is angry with himselfe. That I could not thinke o'this, as well as he?
O, I could beate my infinite blocke-head—!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Come, we must this way.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: How far is't.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Hard by here
Over the way. Now, to atchieve this ring,
He thinkes how to coozen the bearer of the ring. From this same fellow, that is to assure it;
Before he give it. Though my Spanish Lady,
Be a young Gentleman of meanes, and scorne
To share as he doth say, I doe not know
How such a toy may tempt his Ladyship:
And therefore, I thinke best, it be assur'd.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir, be the Ladies brave, we goe unto?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, yes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And shall I see 'hem, and speake to 'hem?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Questions his man. What else? ha'you your false beard about you? Traines.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And is this one of your double Cloakes?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: The best of 'hem.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Be ready then. Sweet Pitfall!

div.head: Act. III. Scene. VI.
div.l: COme, I must busse—

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Away.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I'll set thee up againe;
Offers to kisse. Never feare that: canst thou get ne'r a bird?
No Thrushes hungry? Stay till cold weather come,
I'll helpe thee to an Ousell, or a Field-fare.
She runs in, in haste: he followes. Who's within with Madame?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: I'll tell you straight.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Please you stay here a while Sir, I'll goe in.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I doe so long to have a little venery,
Pug leaps at Pitfall's comming in. While I am in this body! I would taste
Of every sinne, a little, if it might be
After the manner of man! Sweet heart!

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: What would you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Nothing but fall in, to you, be your Blacke-bird,
My pretty pit (as the Gentleman said) your Throstle:
Lye tame, and taken with you; here'i's gold!
To buy you so much new stuffes from the shop,
Traine's in his false cloak brings a false message, & gets the ring. As I may take the old up—

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: You must send, Sir,
The Gentleman the ring.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: There 'tis. Nay looke,
Will you be foolish, Pit.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: This is strange rudenesse.

sp.speaker: Pug
sp.l: Deare Pit.

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: I'll call, I sweare.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Where are you, Sir?
Is your ring ready? Goe with me.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I sent it you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Mere craft followes presently, and askes for it. Me? When? by whom?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A fellow here, e'en now,
Came for it i'your name.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I sent none, sure.
My meaning ever was, you should deliver it,
Your selfe: So was your Masters charge, you know.
Ent. Train's as himselfe againe. What fellow was it, doe you know him?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Here,
But now, he had it.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Saw you any? Traines?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The gentleman saw him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Enquire.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I was so earnest upon her, I mark'd not! The Divell confesseth himselfe coozen'd.
My divellish Chiefe has put me here in flesh,
To shame me! This dull body I am in,
I perceive nothing with! I offer at nothing,
That will succeed!

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.l: Sir, she saw none, she saies.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Satan himselfe, has tane a shape t'abuse me.
It could not be else! Meere-craft accuseth him of negligence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: This is above strange?
That you should be so retchlesse. What'll you do Sir?
How will you answer this, when you are question'd?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Run from my flesh, if I could: put off mankind!
This's such a scorne! and will be a new exercise,
For my Arch-Duke! Woe to the severall cudgells,
Must suffer, He asketh aide. on this backe! Can you no suckers? Sir?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Alas! use of it is so present.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I aske,
Sir, credit for another, but till to morrow?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: There is not so much time, Sir. But how ever,
The Lady is a noble Lady, and will
(To save a Gentleman from check) be intreated Merecraft promiseth faintly, yet comforts him.
To say, she ha's receiv'd it.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Do you thinke so?
Will she be won?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No doubt, to such an office,
It will be a Lady's bravery, and her pride.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And not be knowne on't after, unto him?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That were a treachery! Upon my word.
Be confident. Returne unto your master,
My Lady President sits this after-noone,
Ha's tane the ring, commends her services
Vnto your Lady-Dutchesse. You may say
She's a civell Lady, and do's give her
All her respects, already: Bad you tell her
She lives, but to receive her wish'd commandements,
And have the honour here to kisse her hands:
For which shee'll stay this houre yet. Hasten you
Your Prince, away.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: And Sir, you will take care
Th'excuse be perfect? The Divell is doubtfull.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You confesse your feares.
Too much.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The shame is more, I'll quit you of either.

div.head: Act. VI. Scene. I.
div.l: A pox upo 'referring to Commissioners,
I'had rather heare that it were past the seales:
Your Courtiers move so Snaile-like i'your Businesse.
Would I had not begun wi'you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wee must move,
Madame, in order, by degrees: not jump.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: Why, there was Sr. Iohn Monie-man could jump
A Businesse quickely.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: True he had great friends,
But because some, sweet Madame, can leape ditches,
We must not all shunne to goe over bridges,
The harder parts, I make account are done:
He flatters her. Now 'tis referr'd. You are infinitely bound
Vnto the Ladies, they ha' so cri'd it up!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Doe they like it then?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: They ha' sent the Spanish Lady
To gratulate with you—

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I must send 'hem thankes
And some remembrances.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That you must, and visit 'hem.
Where's Ambler?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Lost to day, we cannot heare of him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Not madame?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: No in good faith. They say he lay not
At home to night, And here has fallen a Businesse
Betweene your Cousin and Master Manly, has
Vnquieted us all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So I heare, madame.
Pray you how was it?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Troth, it but appeares
Ill o'your Kinsmans part. You may have heard,
That Manly is a sutor to me, I doubt not:

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I guess'd it, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And it seemes he trusted
Your Cousin to let fall some faire reports
Of him unto me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Which he did!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So farre
From it, as he came in and tooke him rayling
Against him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How! And what said Manly to him?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Enough, I doe assure you: and with that scorne
Of him, and the injury, as I doe wonder
How Everill bore it! But that guilt undoe's
Many mens valors.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Here comes Manly. Man. madame,
Manly offers to be gone. I'll take my leave—

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: You sha'not goe, i'faith.
I'll ha' you stay and see this Spanish miracle,
Of our English Lady.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Let me pray your Ladiship,
Lay your commands on me some other time.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Now, I protest: and I will have all piec'd,
And friends againe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: It will be but ill soldered!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: You are too much affected with it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I cannot
Madame, but thinke on't for th'injustice.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sir,
Meer-craft denies him. His Kinsman here is sorry. Not I Madame,
I am no kin to him, we but call Cousins,
And if we were, I have no relation
Vnto his crimes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: You are not urged with 'hem.
I can accuse Sir, none but mine owne judgement,
For though it were his crime so to betray me:
I am sure 'twas more mine owne, at all to trust him.
But he therein did use but his old manners,
And favor strongly what he was before.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Come, he will change!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Faith, I must never thinke it.
Nor were it reason in me to expect
That for my sake, he should put off a nature
He suck'd in with his milke. It may be Madame,
Deceiving trust is all he has to trust to:
If so, I shall be loath that any hope
Of mine should bate him of his meanes.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yo'are sharpe Sir.
This act may make him honest!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: If he were
To be made honest, by an act of Parliament,
I should not alter, She spies the Lady Either-side. i'my faith of him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Either-side!
Welcome, deare Either-side! how hast thou done, good wench?
Thou hast beene a stranger! I ha'not seene thee, this weeke.

div.head: Act. IIII. Scene. II.
div.l: EVer your servant, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Where hast'hou beene?
I did so long to see thee.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Visiting, and so tir'd!
I protest, madame, 'tis a monstrous trouble!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And so it is. I sweare I must to morrow,
Begin my visits (would they were over) at Court.
It tortures me, to thinke on'hem.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I doe heare
You ha' cause, madame, your sute goes on.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Who told thee?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: One, that can tell: Mr. Either-side.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, thy husband!
Yes faith, their's life in't, now: It is referr'd.
If we once see it under the seales, wench, then,
Have with 'hem for the great Carroch, sixe horses,
And the two Coach-men, with my Ambler, bare,
And my three women: we will live, i'faith,
The examples o'the towne, and governe it.
I'll leade the fashion still.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: You doe that, now,
Sweet madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, but then, I'll every day
Bring up some new device. Thou and I, Either-side,
Will first be in it, I will give it thee;
And they shall follow us. Thou shalt, I sweare,
Weare every moneth a new gowne, out of it.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Thanke you good madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pray thee call mee Taile-bush
As I thee, Either-side; I not love this, madame.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Then I protest to you Taile bush, I am glad
Your Businesse so succeeds.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Thanke thee, good Either-side.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: But Mr. Either-side tells me, that he likes
Your other Businesse better.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Which?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O, the Toothpicks.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I never heard on't.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Aske Mr. Mere-craft.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Madame? H'is one, in a word, I'll trust his malice,
With any mans credit, Meere-craft hath whisper'd with the while. I would have abus'd!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, if you thinke you doe please me, in this,
You are deceiv'd!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, but because my Lady,
Nam'd him my kinsman, I would satisfie you,
What I thinke of him: and pray you, upon it
To judge mee!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: So I doe: that ill mens friendship,
Is as unfaithfull, as themselves.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Doe you heare?
Ha'you a Businesse about Tooth-picks?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, madame.
Did I ne'r tellt you? I ment to have offer'd it
Your Lady-ship, on the perfecting the pattent.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How is't!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For serving the whole state with Tooth picks;
(Somewhat in intricate Businesse to discourse) but—
The Project for Tooth-picks. I shew, how much the Subject is abus'd,
First in that one commodity? then what diseases,
And putrefactions in the gummes are bred,
By those are made 'of' adultrate, and false wood?
My plot, for reformation of these, followes.
To have all Tooth-picks, brought unto an office,
There seal'd; and such as counterfait 'hem, mulcted.
And last, for venting 'hem to have a booke
Printed, to teach their use, which every childe
Shall have throughout the kingdome, that can read,
And learne to picke his teeth by. Which beginning
Early to practice, with some other rules,
Of never sleeping with the mouth open, chawing
Some graines of mastick, will preserve the breath
Trains his man whispers him. Pure, and so free from taint— ha' what is't? sai'st thou?

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good faith, it sounds a very prety Bus'nesse!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: So Mr. Either-side saies, madame.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Lady is come.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Is she? Good, waite upon her in. My Ambler
Was never so ill absent. Either-side,
How doe I looke to day? Am I not drest,
She lookes in her glasse. Spruntly?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, verily, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pox o' madame,
Will you not leave that?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Yes good Tail-bush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So?
Sounds not that better? What vile Fucus is this,
Thou hast got on?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: 'Tis Pearle.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Pearle? oister-shells:
As I breath, Either-side, I know't. Here comes
(They say) a wonder, sirrah, has beene in Spaine!
Wil teach us all! shee's sent to me, from Court.
To gratulate with me! Pr'y thee, let's observe her,
What faults she has, that wee may laugh at 'hem,
When she is gone.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: That we will heartily, Tail bush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Wittipol enters. O, me! the very Infanta of the Giants!

sp.speaker: MER.
sp.l: Here is a noble Lady, madame, come,
Wittipol is drest like a Spanish Lady. From your great friends, at Court, to see your Ladi-ship:
And have the honour of your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sir.
She do's us honour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray you, say to her Ladiship,
It is the manner of Spaine, to imbrace onely,
Excuses him selfe for not kissing. Never to kisse. She will excuse the custome!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Your use of it is law. Please you, sweete madame,
To take a seate.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, madame, I'have had
The favour, through a world of faire report
To know your vertues, madame,; and in that
Name have deserv'd the happinesse of presenting
My service to your Ladiship!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Your love, madame,
I must not owne it else.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Both are due madame,
To your great undertakings.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Great? In troth, madame,
They are my friends, that thinke 'hem any thing:
If I can doe my sexe (by 'hem) any service,
I'have my ends, madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And they are noble ones,
That make a multitude beholden, madame:
The common-wealth of Ladies, must acknowledge from you.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Except some envious, madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yo'are right in that, madame,
Of which race, I encountred some but lately.
Who ('t seemes) have studied reasons to discredit
Your businesse.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How sweet madames?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay, the parties
Wi'not be worth your pause— Most ruinous things, madame,
That have put off all hope of being recover'd
To a degree of handsomenesse.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But their reasons, madame?
I would faine heare.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Some madame, I remember.
They say, that painting quite destroyes the face—

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O, that's an old one, madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: There are new ones, too.
Corrupts the breath; hath left so little sweetnesse
In kissing, as 'tis now us'd, but for fashion:
And shortly will be taken for a punishment.
Decaies the fore-teeth, that should guard the tongue;
And suffers that runne riot everlasting!
And (which is worse) some Ladies when they meete
Cannot be merry, Manly begins to know him. and laugh, but they doo spit
In one anothers faces!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I should know
This voice, and face too:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Then they say, 'tis dangerous
To all the falne, yet well dispos'd Mad-dames,
That are industrious, and desire to earne
Their living with their sweate! For any distemper
Of heate, and motion, may displace the colours;
And if the paint once runne about their faces,
Twenty to one, they will appeare so ill-favour'd,
Their servants run away, too, and leave the pleasure
Imperfect, and the reckoning als' unpaid.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Pox, these are Poets reasons.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Some old Lady
That keeps a Poet, has devis'd these scandals.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Faith we must have the Poets banish'd, madame,
As Master Either-side saies.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Master Fitz-dottrell?
And his wife: where? madame, the Duke of Droun'd-land,
That will be shortly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Is this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The same.

div.head: Act. IV. Scene. IV.
div.stage: Fitz-dottrell. Mistresse Fitz-dottrell. Pug. to them.
div.l: YOur servant, Wittipol whispers with Manly. madame!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How now? Friend? offended,
That I have found your haunt here?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No but wondring
At your strange fashion'd venture, hither.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: It is
To shew you what they are, you so pursue.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: I thinke 'twill prove a med'cine against marriage;
To know their manners.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Stay, and profit then.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The Lady, madame, whose Prince has brought her here,
He presents Mistresse Fitz-dottrell. To be instructed.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Please you sit with us Lady.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That's Lady-President.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A goodly woman!
I cannot see the ring, though.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, she has it.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But madame, these are very feeble reasons!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So I urg'd madame, that the new complexion,
Now to come forth, in name o'your Ladishipes fucus,
Had no ingredient—

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But I durst eate, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: So doe they in Spaine.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Sweet madame be so liberall,
To give us some o'your Spanish Fucuses!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: They are infinite madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: So I heare they have
Water of Gourdes, of Radish, the white Beanes,
Flowers of Glasse, of Thistles, Rose-marine.
Raw Honey, Mustard-seed, and bread dough-bak'd,
The crums o'bread, Goates milke, and whites of Egges,
Campheere and Lilly-rootes, the fat of Swannes,
Marrow of Veale, white Pidgeons, and pine-kernells,
The seed of Nettles, perse'line, and hares gall.
Limons, thine skind—

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: How, her Ladiship has studied
All excellent things!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But ordinary madame,
No, the true rarities are th'alvagada,
And Argentata of Queene Isabella!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I, what are their ingredients, gentle madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Your Allum Scagliola, or Polidipedra;
And Zuccarino; Turpentine of Abezzo,
Wash'd in nine waters: Soda di gotta;
Grosia di serpe; Porcelleto marino;
Oyles of Lentisco; Zucchi Mugia; make
The admirable Vernish for the face,
Gives the right luster; but two drops rub'd on
With a piece of scarlet, makes a Lady of sixty
Looke at sixteene. But above all, the water
Of the white Hen, of the Lady Estifanias!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O I, that same good madame, I have heard of:
How is it done?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: madame, you take your Hen,
Plume it, and skin it, cleanse it o'the inwards:
Then chop it, bones and all: adde to foure ounces
Of Carrnuacins, Pipitas, Sope of Cyprus,
Make the decoction, straine it. Then distill it,
And keepe it in your galley-pot well glidder'd:
Three droppes preserves from wrinkles, warts, spots, moles,
blemish, or Sun-burnings, and keepes the skin
In decimo sexto, ever bright, and smooth,
As any looking-glasse; and indeed is call'd
The Virgins milke for the face, Oglioreale;
A Ceruse, neither cold or heat will hurt;
And mixt with oyle of myrrhe, and the red Gilli-flower
Call'd Cataputia; and flowers of Rovistico;
Makes the best muta, or die of the whole world.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Deare madame, will you let us be familiar?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Your Ladiships servant.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How doe you like her.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Admirable!
But, He is jealous about his ring, and Mere-craft delivers it. yet, I cannot see the ring.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I must
Deliver it, or marre all. This foole's so jealous.
Madame— Sir, weare this ring, and pray you take knowledge,
'Twas sent you by his wife. And give her thanks,
Doe not you dwindle, Sir, beare up.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I thanke you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: But for the manner of Spaine! Sweet, madame, let us
Be bold, now we are in: Are all Ladies,
There, i'the fashion?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: None but Grandee's, madame.
O'the clasp'd traine, which may be worne at length, too,
Or thus, upon my arme.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And doe they weare
Cioppino's all?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If they be drest in punto, madame.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Guilt as those are? madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Of Goldsmiths work, madame;
And set with diamants: and their Spanish pumps
Of perfum'd leather.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I should thinke it hard
To goe in 'hem, madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: At the first, it is, madame.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: Do you never fall in 'hem?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Never.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I sweare, I should
Six times an houre.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But you have men at hand, still,
To helpe you, if you fall?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Onely one, madame,
The Guardo duennas, such alittle old man,
As this.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Alas! he can doe nothing! this!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I'll tell you, madame, I saw i'the Court of Spaine once,
A Lady fall i'the Kings sight, along.
And there she lay, flat spred, as an Vmbrella,
Her hoope here crack'd; no man durst reach a hand
To helpe her, till the Guarda duenn as came,
Who is the person one l'allowed to touch
A Lady there: and he but by this finger.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Ha'they no servants, madame, there? nor friends?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: An Escudero, or so madame, that waits
Vpon 'hem in another Coach, at distance,
And when they walke, or dance, holds by a hand-kercher,
Never presumes to touch 'hem.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: This's scurvy!
And a forc'd gravity! I doe not like it.
I like our owne much better.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: 'Tis more French,
And Courtly ours.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: And tasts more liberty.
We may have our doozen of visiters, at once,
Make love t'us.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And before our husbands?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Husband?
As I am honest, Tayle-bush I doe thinke
If no body should love me, but my poore husband,
I should e'n hang my selfe.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Fortune forbid, wench:
So faire a necke should have so foule a neck-lace,

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: 'Tis true, as I am handsome!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I receiv'd, Lady,
A token from you, which I would not be
Rude to refuse, being your first remembrance.

sp.speaker: (Fit.
sp.l: O, I am satisfied now!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you see it, Sir.)

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: But since you come, to know me, neerer, Lady,
I'll begge the honour, you will weare it for me,
It must be so.

sp.speaker: Mist. Fit.
sp.l: Surely I have heard this tongue.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What doe you meane Sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Would you ha'me mercenary?
Wittipol gives it Mistresse Fitz-dottrell. Mere-craft murmures. He is satisfied, now he sees it. We'll recompence it anon, in somwhat else.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I doe not love to be gull'd, though in a toy.
Wife, doe you heare? yo'are come in the schoole, wife,
Where you may learne, I doe perceive it, any thing!
How to be fine, or faire, or great, or proud,
Or what you will, indeed, wife; here 'tis taught.
And I am glad on't, that you may not say,
Another day, when honours come upon you,
You wanted meanes. I ha'done my parts: beene,
He upbraids her with his Bill of costs. To day at fifty pound charge, first, for a ring,
To get you entred. Then let my new Play,
To wait upon you, here, to see't confirm'd.
That I may say, both to mine owne eyes, and eares,
Senses, you are my witnesse, sha'hath injoy'd
All helpes that could be had for love or money—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fit.
sp.l: To make a foole of her.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wife, that's your malice,
The wickednesse o'your nature to interpret
Your husbands kindnesse thus. But I'll not leave;
Still to doe good for your deprav'd affections:
Intend it. Bend this stubborne will; be great.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good Madame, whom do they use in messages?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: They commonly use their slaves Madam.

sp.speaker: Tai.
sp.l: And do's your Ladiship.
Thinke that so good, Madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No indeed Madame; I,
Therein preferre the fashion of England farre,
Of your young delicate Page, or discreet Vsher.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And I goe with your Ladiship in opinion,
Directly for your Gentleman-usher,
There's not a finer Officer goes on ground.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If he be made and broken to his place once.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay so I presuppose him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And they are fitter
Managers too Sir, but I would have 'hem call'd
Our Escudero's.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Say I should send
To your Ladiship, who (I presume) has gather'd
All the deare secrets to know how to make
Pastillos of the Dutchesse of Braganza,
Coquettas, Almoiavana's, Mantecada's,
Alcoreas, Mustaccioli; or say it were
The Peladore of Isabella, or balls
Against the itch, or aqua nanfa, or oyle
Of Iessamine for gloves, of the Marquesse Muja;
Or for the head and haire: why, these are offices.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fit for a gentleman, not a slave. They onely
Might aske for your pivety, Spanish-cole,
To burne and sweeten a roome: but the Arcana
He enters himselfe with the Ladies. Of Ladies Cabinets—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Should be else-where trusted.
Yo'are much about the truth. Sweet honoured Ladies,
Let me fall in wi'you. I ha' my female wit,
As well as my male. And I doe know what sutes
A Lady of spirit, or a woman of fashion!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And you would have your wife such.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, madame, aërie,
Light; not to plaine dishonesty, I meane:
But, somewhat o'this side.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I take you, Sir.
H'has reason Ladies. I'll not give this rush
For any Lady, that cannot be honest
Within a thred.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes, madame, and yet venter
As far for th'other, in her Fame—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: As can be;
Coach it to Pimlico; dance the Saraband,
Heare, and talke baudy; laugh as loud, as a larum;
Squeake, spring, do any thing.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: In young company, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Or afore gallants. If they be brave, or Lords,
A woman is ingag'd.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I say so, Ladies,
It is civility to deny us nothing.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: You talke of a Vniversity! why, Hell is
A Grammer-schoole to this!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: But then, The Divell admires him.
Shee must not lose a looke on stuffes, or cloth, madame.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Nor no course fellow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: She must be guided, madame
By the clothes he weares, and company he is in;
Whom to salute, how farre—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I ha'told her this.
And how that baudery too, upo'the point,
Is (in it selfe) as civell a discourse—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: As any other affaire of flesh, what ever.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But shee will ne'r be capable, she is not
So much as comming, madame; I know not how
Shee loses all her opportunities
With hoping to be forc'd. He shews his Pug. I'have entertain'd
A gentleman, a younger brother, here,
Whom I would faine breed up, her Escudero,
Against some expectation's that I have,
And she'll not countenance him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Divell, o'darby-shire.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Blesse us from him!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Divell?
Call him De-vile, sweet madame.

sp.speaker: Mis Fit.
sp.l: What you please, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: De-vile's a prettier name!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: And sounds, me thinks,
As it came in with the Conquerour—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Over smocks!
What things they are? That nature should be at leasure
Ever to make 'hem! Manly goes out with indignation. my woing is at an end.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What can he do?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Lets heare him.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Can he manage?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Please you to try him, Ladies. Stand forth, Divell.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Was all this but the preface to my torment?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come, let their Ladiship see your honours.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: O,
He makes a wicked leg.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: As ever I saw!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Fit for a Divell.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good madame, call him De-vile.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: De-vile, what property is there most required
I'your conceit, now, in the Escudero?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why do you not speake?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A setled discreet pause, They begin their Catechisme. madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I thinke, a barren head, Sir, Mountaine-like,
To be expos'd to the cruelty of weathers—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I, for his Valley is beneath the waste, madame,
And to be fruitfull there, it is sufficient.
Dulnesse upon you! Could not you hit this?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Good Sir—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He then had had no barren head.
He strikes him. You daw him too much, in troth, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I must walke
With the French sticke, like an old vierger, for you.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The Divell praies. O, Chiefe, call me to Hell againe, and free me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Do you murmur now?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Not I, Sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What do you take
Mr. Divele, the height of your imployment,
In the true perfect Escudero?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: When?
What doe you answer?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: To be able, madame,
First to enquire, then report the working,
Of any Ladies physicke, in sweete phrase,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, that's an act of elegance, and importance.
But what above?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, that I had a goad for him.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: To finde out a good Corne-cutter.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Out on him!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Most barbarous!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why did you doe this, now?
Of purpose to discredite me? you damn'd Divell.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sure, if I be not yet, I shall be. All
My daies in Hell, were holy-daies to this!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: 'Tis labour lost, madame?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: H'is a dull fellow
Of no capacity!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Of no discourse!
O, if my Ambler had beene here!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: I, madame;
You talke of a man, where is there such another?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Mr. Devile, put case, one of my Ladies, heere,
Had a fine brach: and would imploy you forth
To treate 'bout a convenient match for her.
What would you observe?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: The color, and the size, madame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And nothing else?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: The Moon, you calfe, the Moone!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I, and the Signe.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Yes, and receits for pronenesse.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Then when the Puppies came, what would you doe?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Get their nativities cast!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This's well. What more?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Consult the Almanack-man which would be least?
Which cleaneliest?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And which silentest? This's well, madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: And while she were with puppy?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Walke her out,
And aire her every morning!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Very good!
And be industrious to kill her fleas?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Yes!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: He will make a pretty proficient.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Who,
Comming from Hell, could look for such Catechising?
The Divell is an Asse. I doe acknowledge it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fitz-dottrel admires Wittipol .The top of woman! All her sex in abstract!
I love her, to each syllable, falls from her.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good madame give me leave to goe aside with him!
And try him a little!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Do, and I'll with-draw, madame,
The Divell praies againe. With this faire Lady: read to her the while.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Come, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Deare Chiefe, relieve me, or I perish.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Lady, we'll follow. You are not jealous Sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, madame! you shall see. Stay wife, behold,
He gives his wife to him, taking him to be a Lady. I give her up heere, absolvtely, to you,
She is your owne. Doe with her what yo will!
Melt, cast, and forme her as you shall thinke good!
Set any stamp on! I'll receive her from you
As a new thing, by your owne standard!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Well, Sir!

div.head: Act. IV. Scene. III.
div.l: BUt what ha'you done i'your Dependance, since?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, it goes on, I met your Cousin, the Master—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You did not acquaint him, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Faith, but I did, Sir.
And upon better thought, not without reason!
He being chiefe Officer, might ha' taine it ill, else,
As a Contempt against his Place, and that
In time Sir, ha'drawne on another Dependance.
No, I did finde him in good termes, and ready
To doe me any service.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: So he said to you?
But Sir, you doe not know him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Why, I presum'd
Because this bus'nesse of my wives, requir'd me,
I could not ha'done better: And he told
Me, that he would goe presently to your Councell,
A Knight, here, i'the Lane—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, Iustice Either-side.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And get the Feoffment drawne, with a letter of Atturney.
For livery and seisen!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: That I knowe's the course.
But, Sir, you meane not to make him Feoffee?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, that I'll pause on!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How now little Pit-fall?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Your Cousin Mr. Ever-ill, would come in—
But he would know if Master Manly were here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No, Mere-craft whispers against him. tell him, if he were, I ha'made his peace!
Hee's one, Sir, has no state, and a man knowes not,
How such a trust may tempt him.

sp.speaker: Fit:
sp.l: I conceive you.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir, this same deed is done here.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Pretty Plutarchus?
Art thou come with it? and has Sir Paul view'd it?

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: His hand is to the draught.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Will you step in, Sir,
And reade it?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: I pray you a word wi'you, Everil whispers against Mere-craft.
Sir Paul Either-side will'd me give you caution
Whom you did make Feoffee: for 'tis the trust
O'your whole State: and though my Cousin heere
Be a worthy Gentleman, yet his valour has
At the tall board bin question'd; and we hold
Any man so impeach'd of doubtfull honesty!
I will not justifie this; but give it you
To make your profit of it: if you utter it,
I can forswere it!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I beleeve you, and thanke you, Sir.

div.head: Act. IV. Scene. VI.
div.l: BE not afraid, sweet Lady: yo'are trusted
To love, not violence here; I am no ravisher,
But one, whome you, by your faire trust againe,
May of a servant make a most true friend.

sp.speaker: Mis. Fit.
sp.l: And such a one I need, but not this way:
Sir, I confesse me to you, the meere manner
Of your attempting me, this morning tooke mee,
And I did hold m'invention, and my manners,
Were both engag'd, to give it a requitall;
But not unto your ends: my hope was then,
(Though interrupted, ere it could be utter'd)
That whom I found the Master of such language,
That braine and spirit, for such an enterprise,
Could not but if those succours were demanded
To a right use, employ them vertuously!
And make that profit of his noble parts,
Which they would yeeld. Sir, you have now the ground,
To exercise them in: I am a woman,
That cannot speake more wretchednesse of my selfe,
Then you can read; march'd to a masse of folly;
That every day makes haste to his owne ruine;
The wealthy portion, that I brought him, spent;
And (through my friends neglect) no joynture made me.
My fortunes standing in this precipice,
'Tis Counsell that I want, and honest aides:
And in this name, I need you, for a friend!
Never in any other; for his ill,
Must not make me, Sir, worse.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: O friend! forsake not
Manly, conceal'd this while, shews himselfe. The brave occasion, vertue offers you,
To keepe you innocent: I have fear'd for both;
And watch'd you to prevent the ill I fear'd.
But since the weaker side hath so assur'd me,
Let not the stronger fall by his owne vice,
Or be the lesse a friend, cause vertue needs him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Vertue shall never aske my succours twice;
Most friend, most man; your Counsells are commands:
Lady, I can love goodnesse in you, more
Then I did Beauty; and doe here intitle
Your vertue to the power, upon a life
Meere-craft taks Wittipol aside, & moves a project for himselfe. You shall engage in any faithfull service,
Even to forfeit.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Madame: Do you heare, Sir,
We have another leg-strain'd, for this Dottrel.
He'ha's a quarrell to carry, and ha's caus'd
A deed of Feoffment, of his whole estate
To be drawne yonder; ha'st within: And you,
Only, he meanes to make Feoffee. H'is falne
So desperatly enamour'd on you, and talkes
Most like a mad-man: you did never heare
A Phrentick, so in love with his owne favour!
Now, you doe know, 'tis of no validity
In your name, as you stand; Therefore advise him
To put in me. (h'is come here:) You shall share Sir.

div.head: Act. IV. Scene. VII.
div.stage: Wittipoll. Mistresse Fitz-dottrel. Manly. Meere-craft. Fitz-dottrell. Ever-ill. Plutarchus.

sp.speaker: FIT.
sp.l: Madame, I have a sute to you; and a fore-hand,
I doe bespeake you; you must not deny me,
I will be graunted.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, I must know it, though.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No Lady; you must not know it: yet, you must too.
For the trust of it, and the fame indeed,
Which else were lost me. I would use your name,
But in a Feoffment: make my whole estate
Over unto you: a trifle a thing of nothing,
Some eighteene hundred.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Alas! I understand not
Those things Sir. I am a woman, and most loath,
To embarque my selfe—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: You will not slight me, madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nor you'll not quarrell me?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: No, sweet madame, I have
Already a dependance; for which cause
I doe this: let me put you in, deare madame,
I may be fairely kill'd. He hopes to be the man.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: You have your friends, Sir,
About you here, for choice.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: She tells you right, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Death, if she doe, what doe I care for that?
Say, I would have her tell me wrong.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why, Sir,
If for the trust, you'll let me have the honor
To name you one.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, you doe me honor, madame:
Who is't?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: This Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, no, sweet madame,
H'is friend to him, with whom I ha'the dependance. She designes Manly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: O, might he be?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: One Wittipol: do you know him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Alas Sir, he, a toy: This Gentleman
A friend to him, no more then I am Sir!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But will your Ladiship undertake that, madame?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Yes, and what else, for him, you will engage me.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: What is his name?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: His name is Eustace Manly.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Whence do's he write himselfe?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Of Middle-sex,
Esquire.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Say nothing, madame. Clerke, come hether,
Write Eustace Manly, Squire o' Middle-sex.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What ha'you done, Sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nam'd a gentleman,
That I'll be answerable for, to you, Sir.
Had I nam'd you, it might ha'beene suspected:
This way, 'tis safe.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Come Gentlemen, your hands,
Everil applaudes it. For witnes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What is this?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: You ha'made Election
Of a most worthy Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Would one of worth
Had spoke it: whence it comes, it is
Rather a shame to me, then a praise.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir, I will give you any Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Be silent then: "falshood commends not truth.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: You do deliver this, Sir, as your deed,
To th'use of Mr. Manly?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes: and Sir—
When did you see yong Wittipol? I am ready,
For processe now; Sir, this is Publication.
He shall heare from me, he would needs be courting
My Wife, Sir.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Yes: So witnesseth his Cloake there.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Fitz-dottrel is suspicious of Manly still. Nay good Sir,— Madame, you did undertake—

sp.speaker: What.
sp.l: What?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: That he was not Wittipols friend.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I heare
Sir, no confession of it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O she knows not;
Now I remember, madame! This young Wittipol,
Would ha' debauch'd my wife, and made me Cuckold,
Through a casement; he did fly her home
To mine owne window: but I thinke I sou't him,
And ravish'd her away, out of his pownces.
I ha' sworne to ha' him by the eares: I fear
The toy, wi' not do me right.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: No? that were pitty!
What right doe you aske, Sir? Here he is will do't you?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wittipol discovers himselfe. Ha? Wittipol?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I Sir, no more Lady now,
Nor Spaniard!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: No indeed, 'tis Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Am I the thing I feard'd?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: A Cuckold? No Sir,
But you were late in possibility,
I'll tell you so much.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: But your wife's too vertuous!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Wee'll see her Sir, at home, and leave you here,
To be made Duke o'Shore-ditch with a project.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Theeves, ravishers.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Crie but another note, Sir,
He would have his deed again. I'll marre the tune, o'your pipe!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Gi'me my deed, then.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Neither: that shall be kept for your wives goood,
Who will know, better how to use it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ha'
To feast with my land?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Sir, be you quiet,
Or I shall gag you, ere I goe, consult
You Master of dependances; how to make this
A second businesse, you have time Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Oh!
What will the ghost of my wise Grandfather,
Wittipol baffles him, and goes out. My learned Father, with my worshipfull Mother
Thinke of me now, that left me in this world
In state to be their Heire? that am become
A Cuckold, and an Asse, and my wives Ward;
Likely to lose my land; ha'my throat cut:
All, by her practice!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, we are all abus'd!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And be so still! Who hinders you, I pray you,
Let me alone, I would injoy my selfe,
And be the Duke o' Dround'd-Land, you ha' made me.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, we must play an after-game o' this

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: But I am not in case to be a Gam-ster:
I tell you once againe—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: You must be rul'd
And take some counsell.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Sir, I doe hate counsell,
As I doe hate my wife, my wicked wife!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But we may thinke how to recover all:
If you will act.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I will not think; nor act;
Nor yet recover; do not talke to me?
I'll runne out o'my witts, rather then heare;
I will be what I am, Fabian Fitz dottrel,
Though all the world say nay to't.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Let's follow him.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. I.
div.l: BUt ha's my Lady mist me?

sp.speaker: Pit.
sp.l: Beyond telling!
Here has been that infinity of strangers!
And then she would ha'had you, to ha' sampled you
With, one within, that they are now a teaching;
And do's pretend to your ranck.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Good fellow Pit-fall
Tel Mr. Meer-craft, I intreat a word with him.
This most unlucky accident will goe neare Pitfall goes out.
To be the losse o'my place; I am in doubt!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: With me? what say you Mr. Ambler?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir,
I would beseech your worship stand betwene
Me, and my Ladies displeasure, for my absence.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O, is this all? I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I would tell you Sir
But how it happnened.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Briefe, good Mr. Ambler,
Put your selfe to your rack: Meere-craft seemes full of business for I have a tasque
Of more importance.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir you'll laugh at me!
But (so is Truth) a verie friend of mine,
Finding by conference with me, that I liv'd
Too chast for my complexion (and indeed
Too honest for my place, Sir) did advise me
If I did love my selfe (as that I do,
I must confesse)

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Spare your Parenthesis,

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: To gi' my body a little evacuation—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Well, and you went to a whore?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No, Sir. I durst not
(For feare it might arive at some body's eare,
It should not) trust my selfe to a common house; Ambler this too with extraordinary speed
But got the Gentlewoman to goe with me,
And carry her bedding to a Conduit-head,
Hard by the place toward Tiburne, which they call
My L. Majors Banqueting-house. Now, Sir, This morning
Was Execution; and I ne'e dream't on't,
Till I heard the noise o'the people, and the horses;
And neither I, nor the poore Gentlewoman
Durst stirre, till all was done and past: so that
He stags I'the Interim, we fell a sleepe againe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay, if you fall, from your gallop, I am gone Sir.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: But when I wak'd, to put on my cloathes, a sute,
I made new for the action, it was gone,
And all my mony, with my purse, and seales,
My hard-wax, and my table-books, my studies,
And a fine new devise, I had to carry
My pen, and inke, my civet, and my tooth-picks,
All under one. But, that which greiv'd me, was
The Gentlewomans shoes (with a paire of roses,
And garters, I had given her for the businesse)
So as that made us stay, till it was darke.
For I was faine to lend her mine, and walke
In a rug, by her, bare foot, to Saint Giles'es.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: A kind of Irish penance! Is this all, Sir?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: To satisfie my Lady.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I will promise you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I ha'told the true Disaster.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I cannot stay wi'you
Sir, to condole; but gratulate your returne.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: An honest gentleman, but he's never at leisure
To be himselfe: He ha's such tides of businesse.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. II.
div.l: O, Call me home againe, deare Chiefe, and put me
To yoaking foxes, milking of Hee-goates,
Pounding of water in a morter, laving
The sea dry with a nut-shell, gathering all
The leaves are falne this Autumne, drawing farts
Out of dead bodies, making ropes of sand,
Catching the windes together in a net,
Mustring of ants, and numbring atomes; all
That hell, and you thought exquisite torments, rather
Then stay me here, a thought more: I would sooner
Keepe fleas within a circle, and be accomptant
A thousand yeere, which of'hem and how far
Out leap'd the other, then endure a minute
Such as I have within. There is no hell
To a Lady of fashion. All your tortures there
Are pastimes to it. 'Twould be a refreshing
Ambler comes in, & survaies him. For me, to be i'the fire againe, from hence.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: This is my suite, and those the shoes and roses!

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Th'have such impertinent vexations,
A generall Councell o' divels could not hit—
Ha! This is he I tooke a sleepe with his Wench,
And borrowed his cloathes. What might I doe to balke him?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Do you heare, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Answer but not to th'purpose.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What is your name, He answers quite from the purpose. I pray you Sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Is't so late Sir?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I aske not o'the time, but of your name, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: I thanke you, Sir. Yes it dos hold Sir, certaine.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Hold, Sir? What holds? I must both hold, and talke to you
About these clothes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: A very pritty lace!
But the Taylor cossend me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: No, I am cossend
By you! robb'd.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Why, when you please Sir, I am
For three peny Gleeke, your man.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Pox o' your gleeke,
And three pence. Give me an answere.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir,
My master is the best at it.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Your master!
Who is your Master.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Let it be friday night.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: What should be then?

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Your best songs Tom o' Bet'lem

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I thinke, you are he. Do's he mocke me trow, from purpose?
Or doe not I speake to him, what I meane?
Good Sir your name.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Only a couple a'Cocks Sir,
If we can get a Widgin, 'tis in season.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: He hopes to make one o'these Scipticks o'me For Scepticks.
(I thinke I name'him right) and do's not flie me.
I wonder at that! 'tis a strange confidence!
I'll proove another way, to draw his answer.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. III.
div.l: IT is the easiest thing Sir, to be done.
As plaine, as fizzling: roule but wi'your eies,
And foame at th'mouth. A little castle-soape
Will do't, to rub your lips: And then a nutshell,
With toe, and touch-wood in it to spit fire,
Did you ner'e read, Sir, little Darrels tricks,
With the boy o' Burton, and the 7 in Lancashire,
Summers at Nottingham? All these do teach it.
And wee'll give out, They repair their old plot. Sir, that your wife ha's bewitch'd you:

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And practised with those two, as Sorcerers.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And ga'you potions, by which means you were
Not Compos mentis, when you made your feoffment.
There's no recovery o'your estate, but this:
This, Sir, will sting.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And move in a court of equity.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: For it is more then manifest, that this was
A plot o'your wives, to get your land.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: I thinke it.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Sir it appeares.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Nay and my cossen has knowne
These gallants in these shapes.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: T'have done strange things, Sir.
One as the Lady, the other as the Squire.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How, a mans honesty may be fool'd! I thought him
A very Lady.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: So do I: renounce me else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: But this way, Sir you'll be reveng'd at height.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Upon 'hem all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes faith, and since your Wife
Has runne the way of woman thus, e'en give her—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Lost by this hand, to me; dead to all ioyes
Of her deare Dottrell, I shall never pitty her:
That could, pitty her selfe.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Princly resolv'd Sir,
And like your selfe still, in Potentiâ.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. IV.
div.stage: Mere-craft, &c. to them. Gvilt-head. Sledge. Plutarchus. Serjants.
div.l: Fitz dottrel askes for his money. GVilt-head what newes?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O Sir, my hundred peices:
Let me ha'them yet.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Yes Sir, officers
Arrest him.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Me?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: I arrest you.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Keepe the peace,
I charge you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Arrest me? Why?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: For better security, Sir. My sonne Plutarchus
Assures me, y'are not worth a groat.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Pardon me, Father,
I said his worship had no foot of Land left:
And that I'll justifie, for I writ the deed.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ha'you these tricks i'the citty?

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: Yes, and more.
Meaning Mere-raft .Arrest this gallant too, here, at my sute.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: I, and at mine. He owes me for his lodging
Two yeere and a quarter.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why M. Guilt-head, Land-Lord,
Thou art not mad, though th'art Constable
Puft up with the pride of the place? Doe you heare, Sirs.
Have I deserv'd this from you two? for all
My paines at Court, to get you each a patent.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: The Project of forks. For what?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Upo' my project o' the forkes.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Forkes? what be they?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: The laudable use of forkes,
Brought into custome here, as they are in Italy,
To th'sparing o'Napkins. That, that should have made
Your bellowes goe at the forge, as his at the furnace.
I ha' procured it, ha'the Signet for it,
Dealt with the Linnen-drapers, on my private,
By cause, I fear'd, they were the likeliest ever
To stirre against, to crosse it: for 'twill be
A mighty saver of Linnen through the Kingdome
(As that is one o'my grounds, and so spare washing)
Now, on you two, had I laid all the profits.
Guilt-head to have the making of all those
Of gould and silver, for the better personages;
And you of those of Steele for the common sort.
And both by Pattent, I had brought you your seales in.
Sledge is brought about. But now you have prevented me, and I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Sle.
sp.l: Sir, I will baile you, at my owne ap-perill.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And Guilt-head comes. Nay choose.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Do you so too, good Father.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: I like the fashin o'the project, well,
The forkes! It may be a lucky one! and is not
Intricate, as one would say, but fit for
Plaine heads, as ours, to deale in. Do you heare.
Officers, we discharge you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Why this shewes
A little good nature in you, I confesse,
But doe not tempt your friends thus. Little Guilt-head,
Advise your fire, great Guilt-head from these courses:
And, here, to trouble a great man in reversion,
For a matter o'fifty on a false Alarme,
Away, it shewes not well. Let him get the pieces
And bring 'hem. Yo'll heare more else.

sp.speaker: Plu.
sp.l: Father.

sp.speaker: Ambler.
sp.l: O Master Sledge, are you here? I ha'been to seeke you.
You are the Constable, they say. Here's one
That I do charge with Felony, for the suite
He weares, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Who? M. Fitz-dottrels man?
Ware what you do, M. Ambler.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Sir, these clothes
I'll sweare, are mine: and the shooes the gentlewomans
I told you of: and ha'him afore a Iustice,
I will.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: My master, Sir, will passe his word for me.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: O, Fitz-dottrel disclaimes him. can you speake to purpose now?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Not I,
If you be such a one Sir, I will leave you
To your God-fathers in Law. Let twelve men worke.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Do you heare Sir, pray, in private.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, what say you?
Briefe, for I have no time to loose.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Truth is, Sir,
I am the very Divell, and had leave
To take this body, I am in, to serve you:
Which was a Cutpurses, and hang'd this Morning.
And it is likewise true, I stole this suite
To cloth me with. But Sir let me not goe
To prison for it. I have hitherto
Lost time, done nothing; showne, indeed, no part.
O'my Divels nature. Now, I will so helpe
Your malice, 'gainst these parties: so advance
The businesse, that you have in hand of witchcraft,
And your possession, as my selfe were in you.
Teach you such tricks, to make your belly swell,
And your eyes turne, to foame, to stare, to gnash
Your teeth together, and to beat your selfe,
Laugh loud, and faine six voices—

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Out you Rogue!
You most infernall counterfeit wretch! Avant!
Do you thinke to gull me with your AEsops Fables?
Here take him to you, I ha'no part in him.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Away, And sends him away. I do disclaime, I will not heare you.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What said he to you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Like a lying raskall
Told me he was the Divell.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How! a good jest!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And that he would teach me, such fine divels tricks
For our new resolution.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: O'pox on him,
'Twas excellent wisely done, Sir, not to trust him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Mere-craft gives the instructions to him and the rest. Why, if he were the Divell, we sha'not need him,
If you'll be rul'd. Goe throw your selfe on a bed, Sir,
And faine you ill. Wee'll not be seen wi'you,
Till after, that you have a fit: and all
Confirm'd within. Keepe you with the two Ladies
And perswade them. I'll to Iustice Either-side,
And possesse him with all. Traines shall seeke out Ingine,
And they to fill the towne with't, every cable
It is to be veer'd. We must imploy out all
Our emissaries now; Sir, I will send you
Bladders and Bellowes. Sir, be confident,
'Tis no hard thing t'outdoe the Divell in:
A Boy o'thirteen yeere old made him an Asse
But t'toher day.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Well, I'll beginne to practice,
And scape the imputation of being Cuckold,
By mine owne act.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yo'are right.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, you ha'put
Your selfe to a simple coile here, and your freinds,
By dealing with new Agents, in new plots.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: No more o'that, sweet cousin.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: What had you
To doe with this same Wittipol, for a Lady?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Question not that: 'tis done.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: You had some straine
'Bove E-la?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: I had indeed.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And, now, you crack fort.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do not upbraid me.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Come, you must be told on't;
You are so covetous, still, to imbrace
More then you can, that you loose all.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: 'Tis right.
What would you more, then Guilty? Now, your succours.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. VI.
div.l: HEre you are lodg'd, Sir, you must send your garnish,
If you'll be privat.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: There it is, Sir, leave me.
Pug is brought to New-gate .To New-Gate, brought? How is the name of Divell
Discredited in me! What a lost fiend
Shall I be, on returne? My Chiefe will roare
In triumph, now, that I have beene on earth,
A day, and done no noted thing, but brought
That body back here, was hang'd out this morning.
Enter Iniquity the Vice .Well! would it once were midnight, that I knew
My utmost. I thinke Time be drunke, and sleepes:
He is so still, and moves not! I do glory
Now i'my torment. Neither can I expect it,
I have it with my fact.

sp.speaker: Ini.
sp.l: Child of hell, be thou merry:
Put a looke on, as round, boy, and red as a cherry.
Cast care at thy posternes; and firke in thy fetters,
They are ornaments, Baby, have graced thy betters:
Looke upon me, and hearken. Our Chiefe doth salute thee,
And least the could yron should chance to confuse thee,
