H'hath sent thee, grant-paroll by me to stay longer
A moneth here on earth, against cold Child, or honger

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: How? longer here a moneth?

sp.speaker: Ini.
sp.l: Yes, boy, till the Session,
That so thou maiest have a triumphall egression.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: In a cart, to be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Ini.
sp.l: No, Child, in a Carte,
The charriot of Triumph, which most of them are.
And in the meane time, to be greazy, and bouzy,
And nasty, and filthy, and ragged and louzy,
With dam'n me, renounce me, and all the fine phrases;
That bring, unto Tiborne, the plentifull gazes.

sp.speaker: Pug.
sp.l: He is a Divell! and may be our Chiefe!
The great superior Divell! for his malice:
Arch-divel! I acknowledge him. He knew
What I would suffer, when he tie'd me up thus
In a rogues body: and he has (I thanke him)
His tirannous pleasure on me, to confine me
To the unlucky carcasse of a Cutpurse
Wherin I could do nothing.

sp.speaker: Div.
sp.l: Impudent fiend,
Stop thy lewd mouth. The great Divell enters, and upbraids him with all his daies work. Doest thou not shame and tremble
To lay thine owne dull damn'd defects upon
An innocent case, there? Why thou heavy slave!
The spirit, that did possesse that flesh before
Put more true life, in a finger, and a thumbe.
Then thou in the whole Masse. Yet thou rebell'st
And murmurst? What one proffer hast thou made,
Wicked inough, this day, that might be call'd
Worthy thine owne, much lesse the name that sent thee?
First, thou did'st helpe thy selfe into a beating
Promptly, and with't endangerdd'st too thy tongue:
A Divell, and could not keepe a body intire
One day! That, for our credit. And to vindicate it,
Hinderd'st (for ought thou know'st) a deed of darknesse:
Which was an act of that egregious folly,
As no one, to'ard the Divell, could ha'thought on.
This for your acting! but for suffering! why
Thou hast beene cheated on, with a false beard,
And a turn'd cloake. Faith would your predecessour
The Cutpurse, thinke you, ha' been so? Out upon thee,
The hurt th'hast don, to let men know their strength,
And that they are able to out-doe a divel
Put in a body, will for ever be
A scarre upon our Name! whom hast thou dealt with,
Woman or man, this day, but have out-gone thee
Some way, and most have prov'd the better fiends?
Yet, you would be imploy'd? Yes, hell shall make you
Provinciall o'the heaters! or Baud-ledger,
For this side o'the towne! No doubt you'll render
A rare account of things. Bane o'your itch,
And scratching for imployment. I'll ha' brimstone
To allay it sure, and fire to singe your nailes off,
But, that I would not such a damn'd dishonor
Sticke on our state, as that the divell were hang'd;
And could not save a body, that he tooke
Iniquity takes him on his back. From Tiborne, but it must come thither againe:
You should e'en ride. But up away with him—

sp.speaker: Ini.
sp.l: Mount, dearling of darknesse, my shoulders are broad:
He that caries the fiend, is sure of his loade.
The Divell was wont to carry away the evill;
But, now, the Evill out-carries the Divell.

div.head: Act. V. Scene. VII.
div.l: A great noise is heard in Newgate, and the Keepers come out affrighted. O mee!

sp.speaker: Kee. 1.
sp.l: What's this?
A peece of Iustice Hall
Is broken downe.
Fough! what a steeme of brimstone
Is here?
The prisoner's dead, came in but now!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Ha? where?
Look here.

sp.speaker: Kee.
sp.l: S'lid I should know his countenance!
It is Gil-Cut-purse, was hang'd out, this morning!

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: 'Tis he!
The Divell, sure, has a hand in this!
What shall we doe?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Carry the newes of it
Unto the Sherifes.
And to the Iustices.
This strange!
And savours of the Divell, strongly!
I' ha' the sulphure of Hell-coale i'my nose.
Fough.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Carry him in.
Away.
How ranke it is!

div.head: Act. V. Scene. VIII.
div.stage: Sir Poule. Meere-craft. Ever-ill. Traines. Pitfall. Fitz-dottrell. to them. Wittipoll. Manly. Mistresse Fitz-dottrell. Ingine. to them Guilt-head. Sledge. to them. Shackles.
div.l: The Iustice comes out wondring and the rest informing him. THis was the notablest Conspiracy,
That ere I heard of.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Sir, they had giv'n him potions,
That did enamour him on the counterfeit Lady—

sp.speaker: Eve..
sp.l: Iust to the time o'delivery o'the deed—

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And then the witchcraft 'gan t'appeare, for straight
He fell into his fit.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Of rage at first, Sir,
Which since has so increased.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: Good Sir Poule, see him,
And punish the impostors.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Therefore I come, madame.

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Let M. Eitherside alone, madame.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Do you heare?
Call in the Constable, I will have him by:
H'is the Kings Officer! and some Cittizens,
Of creadit! I'll discharge my conscience clearly.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Yes, Sir, and send for his wife.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And the two Sorcerers,
By any meanes!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I thought one a true Lady,
I should be sworne. So did you, Either-side?

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: Yes, by that light, would I might ne'r stir else, Tailbush.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: And the other a civill Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: But, madam,
You know what I tould your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: I now see it:
I was providing of a banquet for 'hem
After I had done instructing o' the fellow
De-vile, the Gentlemans man.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Who's found a thiefe, madam.
And to have rob'd your Usher, Master Ambler
This morning.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: How?

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Ile tell you more, anon.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Gi'me some garlicke, garlicke, garlicke, garlicke.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Harke the poore Gentleman, He beginnes his fit. how he is tormented!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: My wife is a whore, I'll kisse her no more: and why?
Ma'st not thou be a Cuckold as well as I?
Ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, ha, &c.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: That is the Divell speakes, and laughes in him.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Do you think so Sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I discharge my conscience. The Iustice interpret all

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And is not the Divell good company? Yes, wis.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: How he changes, Sir, his voice!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And a Cuckold is
Where ere hee put his head, with a Wanion,
If his hornes be forth, the Divells companion!
Looke, looke, looke, else.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: How he fomes!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And swells!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, me! what's that there, rises in his belly!

sp.speaker: Eit.
sp.l: A strange thing! hold it downe:

sp.speaker: Tra. Pit.
sp.l: We cannot, madame.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: 'Tis too apparent this!

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Wittipol, Wittipol, and Manly and Mistr- Fitz-dottrel enter. Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: How now, what play ha'we here.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: What fine new, matters?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: The Cockscombe, and the Coverlet.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: O strange impudence!
That these should come to face their sinne!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And out-face
Iustice, they are the parties, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Say nothing.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Did you marke, Sir, upon their comming in,
How he call'd Wittipol.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And never saw 'hem.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I warrant you did I, let 'hem play a while.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Buz, buz, buz, buz.

sp.speaker: Tay
sp.l: Lasse poore Gentleman!
How he is tortur'd! Mis. Fit Fie, Master Fitz-dottrel!
What doe yo meane to counterfait thus?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: O, His wife goes to him ô,
Shee comes with a needle, and thrusts it in,
She pulls out that, and shee puts in a pinne,
And now, and now, I doe not know how, nor where,
But shee pricks mee heere, and shee pricks me there: ôh, ôh,

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Woman forbeare.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: A practice foule
For one so faire:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hath this, then, credit with you?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Do you believe in't?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Gentlemen, I'll discharge
My conscience: 'Tis a cleare conspiracy!
A darke and divellish practice! I detest it!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: The Iustice sure will prove to be the merrier!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: This is most strange, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Come not to confront
Authority with insolence: I tell you,
I doe detest it. Here comes the Kings Constable,
And with him a right worshipfull Commoner;
My good friend, Master Guilt-head! I am glad
I can before such witnesses, professe
My conscience, and my detestation of it.
Horrible! most unaturall! Abominable!

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: They whisper him. You doe not rumble enough.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Wallow, gnash:

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: O, how he is vexed!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: 'Tis too manifest.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: And give sope to act with. Give him more sope to foame with, now lie still.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: And act a little.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: What do's he now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Shew
The taking of Tobacco, with which the Divell
Is so delighted.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Hum!

sp.speaker: Pov.
sp.l: And calls for Hum.
You takers of Waters and Tobacco,
Marke this.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yellow, yellow, yellow, yellow, &c.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: That's Starch! the Divells Idoll of that colour.
He ratifies it, clapping of his hands.
The proofes are pregnant.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: How the Divel can act!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: He is the Master of Players? Master Guilt-head,
And Poets, too! you heard him talke in rime!
Sir Poule interprets Figgum a Iuglers game. I had forgot to observe it to you, ere while!

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.l: See, he spits fire.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: O no, he plaies at Figgum,
The Divell is the Author of wicked Figgum—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Why speake you not unto him?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: If I had
All innocence of man to be indanger'd
And he could save, or ruine it: I'ld not breath
A syllable in request, to such a fellow,
I'd rather fall.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: ô they whisper, they whisper, whisper, &c.
We shall have more, of Divells a score,
To come to dinner, in me the sinner.

sp.speaker: Eyt.
sp.l: Alas, poore Gentleman!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Put'hem asunder.
Keepe 'hem one from the other.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Are you phrenticke, Sir,
Or what grave dotage moves you, to take part
With so much villany? we are not afraid
Either of law, or tryall; let us be
Examin'd what our ends were, what the meanes,
To worke by; and possibility of those meanes.
Doe not conclude against us, ere you heare us.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will not heare you, yet I will conclude
Out of the circumstances.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Will you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Yes they are palpable:

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Not as your folly:

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will discharge my conscience, and doe all
To the Meridian of Iustice.

sp.speaker: Gui.
sp.l: You doe well, Sir:

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Provide me to eate, three or foure dishes o'good meat,
I'll feast them, and their traines, a Iustice head and braines
Shall be the first.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: The Divell loves not Iustice,
There you may see.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: A spare-rib o'my wife,
And a whores purt'nance! a Guilt-head whole.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Be not you troubled, Sir, the Divell speakes it.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Yes, wis, Knight, shite, Poule, Ioule, owle, foule, troule, boule.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Crambe, another of the Divell's games!

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: Speake, Sir, some Greeke, if you can. Is not the Iustice
A solemne gamester?

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: {non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman},
{non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman},
{non-Roman} {non-Roman} {non-Roman}.

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Hee curses
In Greeke, I thinke.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: Your Spanish, that I taught you.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Qu brémosel ojo de burlas.

sp.speaker: Eve.
sp.l: How? your rest—
Let's breake his necke in jest, the Divell saies,

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Di gratia, Signòr mio se baúete denári fataméne parte.

sp.speaker: Mer.
sp.l: What, would the Divell borrow money?

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Ouy,
Ouy, Monsiur, ùn pàuure Diable! Diablet in!

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: It is the Divell, by his severall languages.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Where's Sir Paule Either-side?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Here, Enter the Keeper of New-gate what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: O! such an accident falne out at Newgate, Sir:
A great piece of the prison is rent downe!
The Divell has beene there, Sir, in the body—
Of the young Cut-purse, was hang'd out this morning,
But in new clothes, Sir, every one of us know him.
These things were found in his pocket.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Those are mine, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: I thinke he was committed on your charge, Sir.
For a new felony

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Hee's gone, Sir, now,
And left us the dead body. But with all, Sir,
Such an infernall stinke, and steeme behind,
You cannot see St. Pulchars Steeple, yet.
They smell't as far as Ware, as the winde lies,
By this time, sure.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Is this upon your credit, friend?

sp.speaker: Sha.
sp.l: Sir, Fitx. dottrel leaves counterfaiting. you may see, and satisfie your selfe.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: Nay, then, 'tis time to leave off counterfeiting.
Sir I am not bewitch'd, nor have a Divell▪
No more then you. I doe defie him, I,
And did abuse you. These two Gentlemen
Put me upon it. (I have faith against him)
They taught me all my trickes. I will tell truth,
And shame the Fiend. See, here, Sir are my bellowes,
And my falle belly, and my Mouse, and all
That should ha'come forth?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, are not you asham'd
Now of your solemne, serious vanity?

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: I will make honourable amends to truth.

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: And so will I. But these are Coozners, still;
And ha'my land, as plotters, with my wife:
Who, though she be not a witch, is worse, a whore.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: Sir, you belie her. She is chast, and vertuous,
and we are honest. I doe know no glory
A man should hope, by venting his owne follies,
But you'll still be an Asse, in spite of providence.
please you goe in, Sir, and here truths, then judge 'hem:
and make amends for your late rashnesse; when,
You shall but here the paines and care was taken,
To save this foole from ruine (his Grace of Droun'd land)

sp.speaker: Fit.
sp.l: My land is droun'd indeed—

sp.speaker: Pou.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.l: And how much
is modest and too worthy wife hath suffer'd
By misconstruction, from him, you will blush,
First for your owne beliefe, more for his actions!
His land is his: and never, by my friend,
Or by my selfe, meant to another use,
But for her succours, who hath equall right.
If any other had worse counsells in't,
(I know I speake to those can apprehend me)
Let'hem repent 'hem, and be not detected.
It is not manly to take joy, or pride
In humane errours (we doe all ill things,
They doe 'hem worst that love 'hem, and dwell there,
Till the plague comes) The few that have the seeds
Of goodnesse left, will sooner make their way
To a true life, by shame, then punishment.

div.head: Notes, typically marginal, from the original text
The Epilogue.
div.l: THus, the Projector, here, is over-throwne.
But I have now a Project of mine owne,
If it may passe: that no man would invite
The Poet from us, to sup forth to night,
If the play please. If it displeasant be,
We doe presume, that no man will: nor we:
